EXIT   X

SUSPICIOUS AND THRESHOLD TRANSACTIONS

Page

Table of Contents

 

Do you remember the scenario?

 

Click here for a reminder

 

 

Does Mr Barnes's transaction raise any grounds for suspicion?

Scenario

Imagine you are an employee of Big Bank. One of your customers, Mr Barnes, has an account in the name of his car dealership business.

 

Today, Mr Barnes deposited $27,000 in cash in his business account. This was unusual for Mr Barnes. He usually deposits third-party cheques or has money electronically transferred into the business account by his customers or by credit card companies.

 

While conducting the transaction, Mr Barnes appears nervous. When you ask him about the transaction, he mumbles something about a new customer and changes the subject.

Yes, unless Mr Barnes has been a Big Bank customer for a long time

Yes, Mr Barnes's transaction raises several grounds for suspicion

No, it is not your responsibility to identify suspicious transactions

 
 
 

That is incorrect

 

It does not matter how long Mr Barnes has been a Big Bank customer. His transaction raises several grounds for suspicion. It is unusual for Mr Barnes to deposit a large amount of cash in his bank account. In addition, his nervous and evasive behaviour could also raise grounds for suspicion. As the owner of a car dealership, Mr Barnes could be a high-risk customer, requiring his transactions to be monitored with extreme care.

That is correct!

 

Mr Barnes's transaction raises several grounds for suspicion. It is unusual for Mr Barnes to deposit a large amount of cash in his bank account. In addition, his nervous and evasive behaviour could also raise grounds for suspicion. As the owner of a car dealership, Mr Barnes could be a high risk customer, requiring his transactions to be monitored with extreme care.

That is incorrect

 

Your organisation has protocols setting out the process of forming a suspicion on reasonable grounds. Mr Barnes's transaction raises several grounds for suspicion. It is unusual for Mr Barnes to deposit a large amount of cash in his bank account. In addition, his nervous and evasive behaviour could also raise grounds for suspicion. As the owner of a car dealership, Mr Barnes could be a high risk customer, requiring his transactions to be monitored with extreme care.
